captions.text:
So about a decade ago I realized that if we
were going to go to Mars with people it would

be really expensive, and so I thought to myself:
what activities have human cultures engaged

in, in the past that were as expensive as
what it might be to go to Mars and what motivated

them to spend that money? I was going to fill
a whole book, "Motivations to do Great Things,

Great Expensive Things," and then I'd find
the task, I'd find the activity that most

closely resembled what it would be to go to
Mars in the 21st century and I'd say, oh,

is that what that culture did with their population,
is that how they raised the money, is that

how they convinced the people? I was going
to fill a whole book of this. It would be

a nice little reference catalog about how
to get something done in modern times.

In conducting that exercise what I found is
that there are only three drivers, not more,

not less, three drivers that account for the
most expensive, ambitious projects humans

have ever undertaken. One of them is the praise
of deity or royalty. That's what got you the

pyramids. They're basically expensive tombstones.
That's what got the cathedral and church building

of Europe. That was a period where huge fractions
of societal investment went into those activities.

There is less of that today, so that's not
really a useful driver to think about how

we might transform the 21st century. Another
driver is war. Nobody wants to die. That gets

you the Great Wall of China. That gets you
the Manhattan Project where we built the bomb.

That gets you the Apollo Project. Another
driver, the search for economic return—nobody

wants to die, nobody wants to die poor. The
search for economic return, that's what is

responsible for the Columbus voyages, the
Magellan voyages, Lewis and Clark figuring

out what is beyond that frontier in hugely
expensive enterprises, conducted by governments.

So if we're going to go to Mars, and if war
is not the driver—because it could easily

become the driver if you get another space
race with someone we view as a military adversary;

I wonder who that might be—but if peaceful
heads prevail, then war is not the driver

available to you. Let's check our list. Well,
kings and gods are not sufficient in modern

times to undergo heavy projects such as that.
What's left? The promise of economic return.

You can go into space, transform society,
change the zeitgeist of your culture, turn

everyone into people who embrace and value
science, technology, engineering and math,

the STEM field. Whether or not people go into
space or serve the space industry they will

have the sensitivity to those fields necessary
to stimulate unending innovation in the technological

fields, and it's that innovation in the 21st
century that will drive tomorrow's economies.

Any frontier in space now involves biologists—we're
looking for life—, chemists, geologists,

physicists, mechanical engineering, electrical
engineers, aerospace engineers, astrophysicists,

all the traditional sciences and engineering
frontiers are captured in any ambitious goal

to explore space. We can recapture those times
and reinvent America. We've already invented

America once before. It's ripe. It's ready
and it's willing, I think, to be invented
again.

title: Neil deGrasse Tyson: The 3 Fears That Drive Us to Accomplish Extraordinary Things

comments.author: Michael Groesbeck

comments.text:
The fear of death or the unknown is a more accurate label to the first 
driving force of accomplishment. Religion itself is a result of the fear of 
death, so naturally every accomplishment attributed to religion or the 
worship of the divine is a consequence of that, but using the pyramids as 
an example for divinity worship is simply inaccurate. The intention of the 
building of the pyramids was to create palaces, not burial grounds, but 
palaces in which the souls of the pharaohs could roam on their way to the 
afterlife. The pharaohs may or may not have been worshiped as god kings, 
either way it's irrelevant, because the tombs (pyramids) weren't meant to 
be a symbol of their divinity but rather a symbol of their status and power 
as well as a "portal" to the afterlife.﻿

The actual main driver for innovation is human intelligence, our brain, as

comments.author: Gandewa Rahary

comments.text:
I think you're misunderstanding the point he's making.  He isn't saying 
that war and greed are good, he's saying that our society simply doesn't 
understand life without it.  Yes, intellect is the main driver in 
innovation, but you have to remember that most of our society is wildly 
ignorant of science, and many are so far gone they may, unfortunately, 
never be.  The scientifically illiterate are the ones who currently hold 
power, and he's simply describing how we deal with them.  Sure, our society 
would highly benefit from more modern ideologies (many of which Tyson 
supports,) but change, unfortunately, isn't that easy.  As I've said, our 
society is rather backwards when it comes to progress, and intellectuals 
have commonly been few and far between throughout history.  He's not saying 
our current position is good, he's simply stating that, if we want 
progress, we need to learn how to deal with the powers-that-be, and try to 
found a more intellectual society in their place.  He's not pro-war, or 
pro-money.  He's trying to find ways to convince the societal elites 
holding us back that progress is worth it.
On a side note, it's a tad harsh to deem someone intellectually invalid on 
the basis of one youtube video, especially one such as this.

comments.text:
I really enjoyed this video because it reaffirmed my belief as to why I am 
pursuing a degree in Chemical Engineering. I am not really quite sure what 
I want to be when I grow up, but a degree of such rigor will never be 
turned away. That being said, I want to become an engineer because I feel 
like it is my service to humanity to gain as much wisdom as I can so that I 
may discover and communicate such wisdoms both old and new.

To reach into space, I am of the indication that we must take care of home 
first. There are a lot of problems here on Earth that need to be tended 
too: World Hunger, Disease, Mediocre Education, Lack of Morale, etc...

I think everyone, of every race, ethnicity and gender, should pursue a 
field of science personally. I understand that the wealth gap is 
increasing, but I dont know anyone who can't get financial aid and/or 
loans. I also understanf that the education system is "flawed" to an 
extent. Maybe in High School education, but in College I think it is 100% 
fair. Sure, maybe High School didn't teach you how to work in College, but 
is it really the High Schools fault you didn't choose to take advanced 
classes or do extracurricular activities? Who's fault is it that people 
decide to watch shit television and proceed to engage in nonintellectual 
activities time and time again? If we had an educated society of 
scientists, then there's no economic crisis, legal/political/diplomatic 
issue, or biological phenomenon that we, as a Society, can not overcome.﻿
comments.author: Brandon Cooper

comments.text:
There is another driver that has the potential to get large projects done, 
but it only has that potential in the information age, so a historical 
overview is likely to miss it. If you think about the number of people and 
hours that have gone into writing the articles on Wikipedia, you will soon 
realize that the scale of this project is much greater than possibly any 
undertaking in human history, including things like the building of the 
pyramids or the Apollo program. Wikipedia has its problems, but its 
existence says a lot about what is possible without economic incentives, or 
threats of force, or the "praise of deity or royalty". The open source 
software that runs almost every internet server on the planet is a very 
similar example.

So what is the driver in these cases? It may be a combination of things, 
the pleasure of finding things out, the desire to share, an obsessive need 
to correct what is incorrect, or various idiosyncratic reasons particular 
to each of the individuals involved. It's almost beside the point what it 
is because it's power comes not from the strength of the drive but from the 
connectedness we have in the information age. It only takes one person to 
have some reason - it doesn't matter what - for contributing to a Wikipedia 
article for absolutely everyone to benefit from it. With 3D printing and 
further advances down the path toward 'universal constructors', this 
collaborative open source phenomenon has the potential to branch out into 
the physical world and conceivably to projects like Mars missions, all 
without economic incentives.﻿
comments.author: cavalrycome

comments.text:
+BigDogJang0 I know you're responding to +Gandewa Rahary, but my original 
point was that you only need a tiny proportion of people to have a sharing 
mindset for everyone to benefit in the information age, which is why things 
like Wikipedia and open source software have been so successful. A tiny 
*proportion* is still a very large *number* of people when we're talking 
about the population of the entire planet, so this could drive enormous 
collaborative projects even if the majority of people are not sharers and 
feel entitled to exclusive financial gains for their work.
comments.author: cavalrycome

comments.text:
+Gandewa Rahary I don't think a society based on sharing is feasible. Of 
course there's a desire to share, but people will only take it to a certain 
point. Most electricity is generated by coal, for example, but who is going 
to risk their lives digging in coal mines just to have what they've 
gathered shared with people who don't mine? When someone works hard for 
something, they have a feeling of entitlement attached to it. It's easy to 
add a little new information to Wikipedia and then detach yourself from it, 
but it's another thing to write a hundred pages of your own research on a 
subject; how would you not want credit or some kind of gain from it? I'm 
not saying people making their hard work free to the public has never 
happened before, but it's something that's hardly expected.
comments.author: BigDogJang0

comments.author: Johanan Boynes

comments.text:
+Timothy Flood The rich are of course to blame ,but historically, it was 
also the rich who manufactured the monetary system itself. Do not be so 
naive to believe that a government (the new feudal kings) will be "nicer' 
to people or more financially sensible. 

As for any economy in the world there is one common thing: all cost 
increase for the people. How are you going to solve that? 

You cannot solve it by equal distribution, as this removes the growth of 
the economy in many ways. But the growth of the economy also produces money 
for the state to tax from and that is the whole reason why the monetary 
system is being held up by the state and bank interests. 

So the whole lie of "distributing" equally boils down to cynical 
capitalism. It requires enormous growth. 
But without that welfare, how do a society stay civilized? well it is 
impossible in a monetary world... 
That is why I am suggesting an RBE, a truly resource-based economy without 
money, like in The Venus project. 

As there are many accumulated benefits of today, money is simply not 
needed. It serves as a block to social responsibility and as a milking cow 
for the elites and warmongers.

itself requires it. 
All monetary systems through history have resulted in a big difference in

There are no exceptions.  All financially modelled societies like socialism 
and capitalism have also produced pretty much only unsustainable economies.

comments.text:
+Timothy Flood The distribution of 'wealth' is the whole problem, as a 
distribution of money can never happen neither just/fair nor efficiently 
(debt/inflation/cost of distributions), relative to existing hierarchies 
who have their interests (state, corporations).

 Think about the following problem, a totally unnecessary one in a modern 
world of technology, knowledge and organized societies: We have to choose 
between basic needs of the people and developing mankind's abilities and 
goals.
The only reason to why this problem occurs is the monetary system itself. 
It doesnt create opportunity but limits.

The socialist answer is of course not the solution. They also believe in 
the monetary system. Their 'equal share" of distribution is nothing but 
getting bankrupt because all financial growth stops, and trying to combine 
it will not work, like we see in today's scandinavia: In Norway the growth 
is enormous from oil industries income and debt-payed trading in the 
society, but the oil business there have to fire loads of people as we 
speak, just as the hospitals do not have money enough for modern equipment.
In Sweden ,the unemployment rate is high and would be higher if not half 
the young population have gone to other countries to find work and become 
citizens there. The cornerstone companies went down, like SAAB and Volvo, 
partially being sold to foreign interests and the money has gone out of the 
country.

In Venezuela, the income is also quite big from the exploitation of natural 
resources but the inflation has been high,not long ago people were robbing 
warehouses because the local currency had dropped so much that people's 
money were not worth a dime anymore.

In USA the debt is enormous. There is no real money to pay anything with 
anymore. An economy resting on a huge loan is itself doomed to go down with 
a crash.

comments.author: Bob Bobson

comments.text:
+Bob Bobson
I'll be honest, you do write alot hahaha. Some if it I scanned. If I miss a 
point just repeat the point I missed. I didn't say there isn't alien life, 
I just think it's unlikely there is intelligent alien life. Intelligent 
alien life would be the big jackpot imo, because you could trade 
technologies/etc... Small alien life could be useful too, but hey there is 
all kinds of bacteria and species even on earth we don't know about + new

 I think Neil also said in his other video 80% of space funding is for war

comments.author: Clifford Zvengrowski

comments.text:
+Clifford Zvengrowski Alright, you have some points, if we just spent 100% 
of our time and resources on technology, and stuff, instead of war and 
killing eachother and stuff, it would be a great thing.  The world would be 
marvelous and it would be pretty close to paradise, but it isn't that way. 
 Do you know how the United States got out of the great depression?  WWII. 
 Granted, FDR did help a little, but there's only so many parks that could 
have been made.  War got the economy running.  For the Cold War, we made 
HUGE advancements in technology, because there was a cause.  The space race 
got us buying things from companies, boosting the economy.  

It seems that you didn't read my entire post, and that is somewhat 
annoying, because it seems to be feeding part of your argument.  There are 
other planets that we could live on, and there is a high probability of 
aliens in our solar system.  Not necessarily as advanced as us, but 
possibly as advanced as about a shark, possibly living in the waters of a 
moon. 

I never said computers didn't exist before the space race (which is what 
I'm assuming you mean by 'the space war'). I said laptops exist as you know 
them because of the space race.  Computers were already creating algorithms 
in the 1940's.  As for that 99%, I'm pretty sure that that is close, 
because a lot of objects were around before the space race, however, 
without space exploration there would not be GPS and Satellite TV, and 
various other things people rely on, on a day to day basis. (Can you think 
of a way that would be as inexpensive as GPS to get you exactly where you 
want to go, from where you are right now? Neither could a shitton of other 
people [please excuse my language])

I agree, your broken arm is more important to you than your laptop.  It is 
for most people, I think myself included.  We are working on making broken 
arms heal faster. We are working on soo many different things in this 
country, in this world that no one can even perceive the amount of work and 
money going into all of them.  But completely excluding space doesn't seem 
smart to a great deal of very smart individuals.  Why is this? Because it 
is important.  Getting to know your surroundings, exploring things. 
Possibly finding more life.  Possibly finding a new home, for our expanding 
population, and our increasingly difficult climate position.  Please don't 
be ignorant of anything, including space.
comments.author: Bob Bobson

comments.text:
First of all, I am 100% sure computers/99% of everything we have would 
exist regardless of "the space war" You really don't need war, or space 
exploration to have technology, in fact if we spent less time killing each 
other and more time doing science I am sure science would be 10X more 
advanced. If you just spent a ton of money on micro-technology you would 
have microprocessors etc... Next... let's just say you are right... Lets 
say you really do need space exploration for a laptop... well guess what... 
my broken arm is a much larger issue than having a laptop. Lastly it 
probably isn't profitable. It costs billions to launch 1 rocket. At this 
point in time it's still a million times easier to dig deep in earth than 
launch a rocket.. + you gotta add the cost of all the equipment needed to 
extract stuff.
 + rockets crash. I would say space exploration would be a worthwhile 
endeavor BEFORE we learned there is no nearby intelligent aliens, or super 
awesome planets we could live on. But it's not worthwhile anymore. If you 
were on some island it's worth exploring, but if all you find is just water 
for a million miles, and you don't have a boat that can go any further it's 
stupid to waste time exploring
comments.author: Clifford Zvengrowski

comments.text:
+Clifford Zvengrowski Well,  because it could actually be quite profitable 
to go to, say Mars. Mars actually has all of the natural resources needed 
to construct a viable human civilization.  Did I mention that there IS in 
fact water on Mars?  There was water on Mars before there was water on the 
Earth, that means it probably had life before we did.  Experts say the 
chance of finding life on Mars is over 50%.  Europa, and Enceladus both 
probably have liquid water on them, which also means they both probably 
have, and can sustain life (so we might be able to live there)  
It's true, investments in other fields of science could be more effective, 
and lucrative now, but space is revolutionary.  Do you know how many things 
you have in your house that were at least somewhat a product of the space 
race? Your smoke detector was originally made for the space station, 
laptops were invented so astronauts could move more freely with computers, 
now you like TV, right? Thank the space race for your Satellite TV.  You 
were talking about healthcare? Ever heard of Telemedicine? Space race. GPS 
Space Race. I'm just pointing out that going to space has huge byproducts. 
 Back to your original comment: "space is dumb...", "..let's just forget 
about it.". I don't know how space could be smart (although some people are 
theorizing that the universe is actually a consciousness), so I don't think 
it could be dumb either.  We should not forget about space, but lets say we 
did: lets not send anymore sattelites up there, so you can have nice 
directions to wherever you want to go, because no more GPS, lets just 
ignore the Moon (which helps tidal cycle)  Let's just ignore what might be 
out there.  There might be primitive life on Europa or Enceladus, heck some 
scientists have even proposed the existence of life in the clouds of 
Venus(where it isn't as hot).  You don't wanna know where everything came 
from, what might be out there?  Someone once said "..there is no cure for 
curiosity", and it seems you have found one, although, hopefully you have 
just caught it again :)   +Kachun Wong Let's not say that.  This fellow is 
mislead, we should try to help him, instead of hurt him. I encourage you to 
do the same with everyone.  Help expand everyone's horizons, in order to 
not be ignorant. Thank you.

comments.author: 2hafstylezk

comments.text:
With war you could group "avoidance of Death". Consider government mandated 
vaccines, for example.

One of the issues facing a rapidly advancing civilization is organization 
and regulation, which is mainly the realm of government. This produces a 
problem in the U.S. today, because Republican ideas forbid a government to 
make money off anything or "own" anything, but they also don't want a 
government to have taxes and they also don't want a government to have 
deficits. In short, republicans only want governments to give money to big 
businesses, but they forbid the government to make money from any source. 
Of course this is unreasonable, but it's what they really want.

A practical government in the 21st century should own solar and wind farms. 
I said "own". Not lease or give permits. By cutting out the middle-men of 
capitalistic energy corporations, the government could provide cheaper, 
cleaner energy at a lower cost, and still make "tax revenue" in the form of 
a 10% profit margin. The total cost to consumers would be less, and such 
energy farms can grow exponentially through re-investments.

This is what a practical civilization would do, and it in no way violates 
human rights.

An acre of solar panels can collect as much energy in 3 days as is 
collected in Ethanol from Corn in an entire growing season. Yet our nation 
wastes nearly half of it's farmland on producing Ethanol...

If the U.S. government bought up land and made solar farms, it could 
produce so much energy we could profit by exporting energy at no long-term 
resource cost. instead we import oil by the billions of barrels.﻿

comments.author: Naiuhz

comments.text:
I really don't like the development of our modern "religion of progress." 
Sure, engineers and scientists are great, but the way this guy talks about 
them--as if we could never have enough--is a bit alarming. There's a very 
important other half of this discussion I wish he had touched upon: namely, 
about specifically why it is necessary to facilitate "the next big 
transformation." I'm certainly not saying that such a thing might not 
ultimately benefit mankind, but the idea (perhaps dogma) that history is 
simply a grand upward trajectory of progress and development really 
encourages us not to reflect, in a more humanistic way, on our current 
circumstances but instead pushes us primarily to just keep on "stoking the 
furnace" of some grand industrial-scientific vehicle that will somehow 
deliver us to a "better" future. I argue that one cannot become so direly 
hung-up about the means to sustaining life without also becoming seriously 
invested in the question of what it is to embody a meaningful, human 
existence—lest one seriously start to loose one's humanity.﻿

comments.text:
@ Big Think - hello, hi, how are ya? Somebody please tell this guy that 
there are human technologies at play for decades, yes, decades orbiting 
Mars and NOT revealing the ancient architectures and the usual leftovers. 
When Apollo 11 astronuts stepped onto the surface of the moon, what do you 
think they saw lining the rim of that ridge on the Sea of tranquility? If 
they had turned the cameras in that direction we would have seen a virtual 
parade of extraterrestrial craft witnessing the "event". This guy is 
rigidly ensconced in his definitions and if he would actually perceive with 
his heart instead of his physical mind he would, in the appropriate mood, 
make contact with civilizations that have, shall we say, much to share with 
homo sapien who are, know it or not, actually "evolving" into what some 
E.T.s refer to as "homo galactus" and when a human allows their natural 
self (bereft of outdated definitions) to "shine" then communication with 
other civilizations manifests just as naturally. Your cynicism does not 
serve you. Fear, as expressed in your culture, is a messenger saying "hey - 
you have definitions that are out of alignment with your core being!" What 
would I have to believe is true in order to experience the emotion that we 
call fear? When our energy is filtered through a negative (separative) 
belief then we experience fear. That same energy (we only have ONE energy) 
is filtered through the preferred belief that is in alignment with who we 
really are then that same energy is experienced as passion, joy, love and 
synchronicities that are reflective of unconditional love become a way of 
life. Everything is here and now. Too simple? Be well.﻿

It was "astronomically" cheaper to sail to the Americas than for earthlings

the Spaniards found American gold they only needed to lift it and lower it 
a few meters and then use the free Sun driven winds to bring it home to the 
bank. Riches on Mars must be lifted hundreds of kilometers, propelled by

so premature that it's presently based on massive government subsidizing of

I think an enormously expensive project of ensuring every human being on 
the planet has sufficient food, education, and a quality standard of living 
would reap far more economic benefit than sending people to Mars.

Another might be finding a way to reducee or reverse environmental 
destruction.

Neil names three drivers of such arguably expensive projects, yet one of 
the most expensive projects ever undertaken by mankind, the Apollo moon 
landings, were driven by a competitive, nationalistic desire to be the 
first to the moon. They resulted in no great economic return, nor did they 
do anything to reduce the tensions between the two great superpowers of the 
time, the USA and the USSR, nor were they done with the desire to appease a 
deity. 

Whence cometh the Apollo moon landings, then?﻿

comments.author: Hazel Emerson

comments.text:
+RoarOfDamnation I agree with you completely, and I haven't forgotten the 
social sciences.

I have a problem with admittedly smart folks like Dr. Tyson when they speak 
out of their area of expertise (in this case, astronomy and astrophysics) 
as if their opinions on unrelated topics, like economics, history, etc. are 
as valid as their expertise in their area of study and licensure. 
Especially when that area of expertise is in the hard sciences, like Dr. 
Tyson, and the topics being discussed are in the social sciences. 

Yes, Dr. Tyson is a bright guy, but in the areas of psychology, religion, 
and economics, his knowledge and beliefs are not sacrosanct, and should 
carry no more weight than mine or yours or anybody else's, except for 
another academic in economics, religion, or science, in which case his 
views should carry less.

He's wrong about the motivations for the Apollo missions, as anyone who 
lived through that time, and who has a good grasp of psychology and 
economics in general, and particularly as it relates specifically to the 
United States' space program, can attest. The general consensus is that the 
scientific "gains" of the space program were hardly justified by the money 
budgeted to the program.

Scientific study and exploration is extraordinarily important; so is 
providing a reasonable standard of living for citizens. I think the 
greatest gains for the US as a country would be garnered by improving 
education, housing, and nutrition; and the that the gains from such a 
"social experiment" would be far greater and enduring than another 
telescope, satellite, or manned landing on the moon or another planet.
comments.author: Anon Amos

comments.text:
+Anon Amos Scientific knowledge goes beyond the natural sciences, everyone 
forgets social sciences, which address the very issues we get here, so yeah 
it seems that all our problems are from ignorance of science, assuming that 
greed and selfishness comes from this.

Also the Apollo moon landings were clearly a display of power, military and 
technological superiority, deep within the core of that thing known as 
warfare.
comments.author: RoarOfDamnation

comments.text:
+Tucker Plowden I'd be interested in hearing where Tyson addresses any of 
those issues.All I hear him addressing is how astronomy and space 
exploration should get top priority. Considering he's an astrophysicist, 
tis is hardly surprising. 

Tyson seems to believe that all of the world's problems are due to 
ignorance of science, and that's where we part company. It's an attitude 
that completely overlooks the fact that most of the world's problems have 
far more to do with inequality engendered by politics and current 
neoclassical economic policy.

I greatly respect Tyson's intellect and achievements, but I think he's just 
way off on this.
comments.author: Anon Amos

comments.text:
niel degrasse Tyson has hit on that very subject about if we cant stop wars 
on earth than maybe we cant go to deep space. and the Apollo moon landing 
was at heart a mission to show military capability.
comments.author: Tucker Plowden

comments.text:
+Derek M LOL! Only a jerk thinks labeling me as a "tree hugger" is somehow 
an argument, or addresses any issues I've raised. You're basically 
admitting you have no intelligent response and are now sticking out your 
tongue at me. Grow up and learn how to debate intelligently and 
persuasively.

I never said I don't think humanity shouldn't be exploring the cosmos. I 
merely said that we have other pressing problems that deserve as much or 
more attention.

Scientists may be working on the world's problems, and I'm sure they'll 
solve many of them in my own lifetime. In fact, scientists have solved many 
problems - we've left the planet, albeit on a small scale, and eliminated 
smallpox. We've nearly doubled life expectancy in much of the developed 
world. We have instant communication and the Internet.

But even Norman Borlaug's Green Revolution hasn't solved the problem of 
hunger, and neoclassical economic policies haven't solved poverty. Open 
your eyes, dude. We have disease, poverty, war, and famine on a scale no 
one could have dreamed of 500 years ago.

Most of the world's problems have little to do with science, and science 
won't solve all or many of them. Issues like environmental degradation, 
hunger, and poverty owe more to politics and economics than science.

You don't have to be a "tree hugger" to understand that environmental 
degradation, habitat, destruction, and global warming are some of the most 
pressing problems we have today. You don't have to be a tree hugger to 
understand that any species that shits where it eats is doomed to 
extinction.

I want to leave my nephews and niece a world where they can live 
peacefully, and reach their full potential as human beings, without fear of 
war, hunger, disease, and poverty. Addressing those issues is going to take 
a lot more than just throwing dollars and science at them.
comments.author: Anon Amos

comments.text:
TL;DR

Point being, the problems of the world are being worked on by many 
scientists. If you don't believe that this part of science should be 
exploring the corners of the cosmos, then stick with your tree hugging.
comments.author: Derek M (Nemesis64)

comments.text:
+Derek M Oh come on man. Quit being so apathetic about the living standards 
of billions of your fellow human beings on the planet. You don't give a 
shit if people are starving and have no homes or education?

I think eliminating poverty, ignorance, hunger, and disease globally would 
be quite an EXTRAORDINARY thing, wouldn't you agree?

Sure, I love science. I remember watching the Apollo 11 moon landing in 
1969. Where were you? As a kid growing up in the 1960s and 1970s, the space 
program was a source of wonder AND pride that my country had landed men on 
the moon, and that human beings had been there, walked around, and 
increased our knowledge of the universe in many areas of science. But the 
Apollo program was more about nationalistic pride and outdoing the USSR, 
than scientific exploration. We might have learned a bit, but even 
scientists will tell you that the amount of scientific knowledge gained was 
hardly worth the billions spent.

AND we got Tang in the bargain as well.

But if you've worked for the NYC Dept. of Education, and had to deal with 
the lack of materials and resources as a teacher (including science 
teachers having to purchase their own materials out of their own pockets), 
you might think differently.

It took 2 billion1969 dollars to land men on the moon, at a time when tens 
of millions of people right here in the US lived in grinding poverty. 45 
years later, it is even worse. Going to the moon is impressive, but it 
didn't solve any problems here on Earth.

We need to solve the issue of poverty, ignorance, and environmental 
destruction here on Earth; otherwise, we will just take all those problems 
with us to the moon, Mars, and the outer planets.

Unmanned missions and probes are far less expensive, far less dangerous, an 
provide far more scientific knowledge than sending people.

I appreciate the caps on words like IGNORANT and LEARNED, but I'm hardly 
the guy you want to be shouting at. I have degrees in EDUCATION and 
COMPUTER SCIENCE and make a six-figure INCOME as an IT PROFESSIONAL and 
CONSULTANT to the healthcare industry. I also graduated with a perfect 4.0 
average and have an IQ of 170.

But thanks for the response. I love being lectured at.

Now, why don't you go and do some research about the space program and 
global poverty and come back far less ignorant and biased, and then we'll 
talk.
comments.author: Anon Amos

comments.text:
Oh come on, man. Quit being closed minded about the whole thing. Would you 
rather sit here and NOT explore the vast corners of the universe? Even if 
it didn't bring economic boosts after we landed on the moon, we still 
discovered so much more. We LEARNED, and therefore we aren't as closed 
minded and IGNORANT. Also, you are keeping this limited to an "economic" 
benefit. What does the title of the video say? The 3 fears that drive us to 
accomplish EXTRAORDINARY things, not economic things.
comments.author: Derek M (Nemesis64)

comments.text:
Is it strange that I have a man crush on him? This guy may be the smartest 
guy alive.﻿
comments.author: hooah9422

comments.text:
It will be a tragedy if homo sapiens spends billions of dollars, euros, 
pounds or yen doing this while there are people dying of malnourishment on 
this planet. I'm very positive about scientific endeavour but surely we 
should utilise this to fix the problems already evident to us before 
exploratory missions? Although these excursions undoubtedly fascinating, 
given their context, they'd be pretty damn inhuman.﻿
comments.author: Rory Allen

comments.text:
You are effectively making an issue of strategy into a simplistic view of 
one OR the other. Atleast 10times the amount of the worldwide space budget 
is spent on charity a year, that's CHARITY by organisations alone, its also 
a VERY conservative figure. 100times that amount is spent on worldwide 
military budget WTF? Why not cut some fucking pennies there if you are 
going to look at budgeting. Even if you were able to get anyone funding the 
care of millions more dying people, what is the end game?

Space funding has been dying. And everyone forgets how the moon landing 
changed the course of history. It changed something in the human psyche. It 
fucking inspired so much good in the world. If you want to change humankind 
forever again and inspire good in everyone, we need to send the next 
generation to Mars. There are too many reasons why we have to do it and 
there's no alternative.
comments.author: D Andersen

comments.text: +Akira Mishtokaru Bunny....awwgasm. And I'm a man : / Mmhmmm
comments.author: Wub Wubs

comments.text:
+ROBLOXobama1337 You are right! The space program is one of the things that 
needs more funding, the others are education and research to help humanity 
technological advance. There are lots of useless drain holes in the budget 
http://i3.kym-cdn.com/photos/images/original/000/621/972/455.jpg
comments.author: Akira Mishtokaru

comments.text:
Our space program gets about 0.4% of the federal budget. If you think that 
you could solve all of the world's problems with that money, then by all 
means, shut down the space program. What's that? You can't? Then let us 
continue our exploration of the final frontier.
comments.author: ROBLOXobama1337

comments.text:
+ExVentoPax2 That sounds more like the military budget than charity 
expenses, which are actually compensation for the mess created after the 
military budget was put into effective action...
comments.author: RoarOfDamnation

comments.text:
on the contrary it is not a waste, if you truly cared about where our money 
was spent, you would be arguing about the massive amount of money we send 
to other countries as foreign aid in the HUNDREDS of billions, or the fact 
that we spent over a TRILLION the past 14 years in the middle east. Yet 
here you are complaining about the fact that if we gave NASA several 
billion that it would be a fundamental waste.

If you watched Tysons other videos about this, NASA's budget on a single US 
Dollar equals to half of a penny, the amount of money it gets from a dollar 
does not even cut into the ink on that bill. NASA's entire budget since the 
day it was created was still less than the bailout or stimulus package 
Obama authorized. 0.005 cents got us to the moon, got us the space shuttle 
program, helped fund ISS and among hundreds of other things. Please don't 
try to patronize me or anyone about spending money on science. Ever.
comments.author: ExVentoPax2

comments.text:
Their whole ideology is essentially "might makes right" though they won't 
use those exact words. The poor are deemed weak and thus worthy of death. 
while the current beneficiaries of this system view themselves as superior 
believing their wealth is proof of their harder work and stronger 
character.
comments.author: Kevork Aroyan

comments.text:
+ninjabonez86 Ralph Nader would hug you. He has even talked about the 
outcome of what if everyone owned a chicken in the household.
comments.author: Wub Wubs

comments.text:
I see your point but I don't think that it's a question of just spending 
money: there is food, but it's not evenly distributed. Also, as someone 
else here pointed out the population is steadily growing out of control.
comments.author: picarochi

comments.text:
The entire world's population could all live in the state of texas (if all 
of texas was like new York). I agree with overpopulation but its mainly 
industry that needs to be done away with. if everybody grew their own crops 
and raised their own chickens, and otherwise were more self sufficient then 
that would create a stronger species living within the natural order of 
life on Earth.
comments.author: ninjabonez86

comments.text:
I agree that we need to change the way the 1% hold more wealth than the 
99%, but this would not solve the food/sickness problems. Basically, 
governments keep a large percentage of the people near or in poverty to 
MAKE them work to live; if not, and everyone could afford to live ok, who 
would 'bother' to work.
That notwithstanding, the population is still increasing faster than we can 
sustain.... so either we cull the population (not nice but necessary), we 
find other worlds to live on (very earthlike worlds (none in this solar 
system), or we create technology that can feed/fuel/house people in a 
'green' way.
This is why we need to invest in technology that matters, not tech that 
makes money for the owners (Google/MS/drug companies/facebook etc) but tech 
like working space drives, like the replicators in star trek, like the not 
so far-fetched as you thought warp drives (Alcubierre warp bubble).
Science fiction has become reality in so many ways, who is to say we cannot 
achieve it with the right support... then maybe the stars are within reach.
comments.author: fran fabregas

comments.text:
+Rory Allen
We have given 3D printers to 3rd world countries so that they may be able 
to print limbs for people who have been amputated due to war and conflict. 
Tell me how that is not a beautiful use of robotics and programming to 
lessen the suffering of people. That is merely one example; through doing 
some research, I am sure you and others can find many more examples and 
uses for such technology.
comments.author: Vizaru

comments.text:
The bitter truth is that humanitarian aid and helping those in need has no 
economical return! That's why people don't give that much to charity.
  But we can change that! Imagine that say: "If you give a man a fish, you 
will feed him for a day and he will be hungry again and ask for more. Give 
that man a fishing rod and teach him to fish, and he could feed himself, 
sell the fish and become economical sustainable" And that's the solution; 
humanity needs to invest in other people, in order to make them productive 
members of the society and thus make life better for those in need and for 
the donors in return.
comments.author: Akira Mishtokaru

comments.text:
their is twice the amount of food grown capable of feeding the world 
population. although it rarely makes it to the starving because their is no 
money in giving people food. if countries placed more investments in 
welfare at first but also education for all then people wouldn't be as 
malnourished, less violence, less , less drug abuse, etc.
comments.author: ninjabonez86

comments.text:
+fran fabregas In short, solving our food crisis that should not be, is a 
low priority.
To get rich people to live longer and to exploit the resources of other 
planets under a consumerism agenda is and will be a must, a must of the 
highest priority. This is not also true but also the most probable thing, 
hey fuck you David Hume!
comments.author: RoarOfDamnation

comments.text:
The fact that people are malnourished is an indicator of the inability of 
the economies to feed the burgeoning populace. The search for alternative 
places to live, greater sources of wealth, advancement in technology far 
outweighs the concern over feeding peoples who can't or won't govern 
themselves adequately. Yes, I feel for those without food. Yes I wish it 
wasn't so. Look at the incredibly wealthy, who never have to want... they 
all die. We need to look at two things; first, getting off this one planet 
and secondly, extending life, whether it be by genetic manipulation or by 
transference of conscient entity to a new body.
Let's be certain about this, current population growth in poor, badly fed 
areas is unsustainable. and for god's sake, let's keep religion out of 
this... it is only powermongering for people who don't know any better.
comments.author: fran fabregas

comments.text:
You know it seems that humanity is inhuman, because the drivers for big 
projects like ending poverty would need some really selfish motives behind 
them, so the question is, how can we make a project to end inequality that 
is economically appealing enough to attract enough investors and resources 
to it, and we have to do this having in mind that those very investors may 
as well seek to increase the economic difference by the end of the project 
by becoming more rich, of course the upside would be that the poor become 
more rich too, but can this be done? and if so how? and if so are they 
people willing to do it?
comments.author: RoarOfDamnation

comments.text:
But you clearly don't care about any of these things nor do you realize how 
small NASA's budget even has to be to make its achievements.

The bank bailout was bigger than NASA's entire budget since it's inception.
comments.author: DOTA2FroggyStyle

comments.text:
Also it's not just the science itself that drives change with space 
exploration.

There was a massive shift in cultural thought in all first world countries 
where people had access to the photographs taken of the Lunar sunrise over 
the Earth.
After we saw how fragile and beautiful are planet was in an almost 
insignificant part of the universe we started making changes: Clean Air 
Act, Clean Water Act, the addition of the catalytic converter, the 
organization Doctor's Without Borders (as Tyson has pointed out, where do 
you even get that name?  You didn't see maps without the borders of the 
countries on them until the Lunar sunrise), etc...
comments.author: DOTA2FroggyStyle

comments.text:
+Rory Allen
All 3 have dude.

You have no experience working on a ranch clearly if you don't know how 
complex John Deer tractors have gotten in the last 30 years.  Fuel 
efficiency is a big deal when you're handling crops; the robotics kick in 
with developing new means for better cultivating, planting, etc..; the 
programming is necessary in order to achieve the previous 2.

Furthermore, you have MASSIVE improvements in medicine alone that make it 
easier and more accurate for a doctor to diagnose problems.  Again, NASA 
gave us the MRI.
comments.author: DOTA2FroggyStyle
